title: Ticket #2942: Leaking job directories in SPOOL
description:
See thread "Leftovers of checkpointed jobs accumulate in SPOOL" on condor-users https://lists.cs.wisc.edu/archive/condor-users/2012-March/msg00052.shtml https://lists.cs.wisc.edu/archive/condor-users/2012-March/msg00071.shtml https://lists.cs.wisc.edu/archive/condor-users/2012-April/msg00075.shtml

Observed behavior:

  • Using DMTCP checkpointing on vanilla jobs
  • Job is evicted at least once
  • Job exits spool (via normal termination or condor_rm)
  • Job's directory in spool isn't removed
remarks:
2012-Apr-13 11:36:28 by adesmet:
Based on the reports, when the shadow exits/is evicted, it fails to remove the swap sandbox. This is an error reported by the shadow. 13 is Permission denied. 

Failed to remove /var/spool/condor/3029/0/cluster3029.proc0.subproc0.swap: Permission denied (errno 13)

Then, when the shadow exits the second time, the schedd complains that the actual sandbox can't be removed. 39 is Directory not empty. 

Failed to remove /var/spool/condor/3029/0/cluster3029.proc0.subproc0: Directory not empty (errno 39)

2012-May-25 14:30:22 by adesmet:
Verified, and pretty easily. Verified on the head of V7_8-branch as of May 20th, 2012. Also present in 7.6.7, as released.

  1. Start Condor as root, configured to use the "condor" user.
  2. Submit a job as a non-condor, non-root user. An example submit file and executable are below.
  3. Wait for the job to start running
  4. condor_vacate
  5. Observe the contents of the spool directory. A representative snapshot follows.
  6. Allow the job to restart and finish
  7. Observe that the job's spool subdirectory is still present. A representative snapshot is below.

Submit: 

executable=executable
arguments=60
output=eraseme.out
error=eraseme.err
log=eraseme.log
when_to_transfer_output=on_exit_or_evict
should_transfer_files=true
notification=never
initialdir=output
queue

executable: 

#! /bin/sh
/bin/touch eraseme-touched-file
/bin/date >> eraseme-dated-file
#/bin/chmod 000 eraseme-touched-file
/bin/hostname
/usr/bin/whoami
/bin/echo Sleeping for $1
/bin/sleep $1
/bin/echo DONE

Snapshot after condor_vacate

drwxr-xr-x 3 condor  condor  4096 May 25 14:14 ./1

drwxr-xr-x 2 adesmet adesmet 4096 May 25 14:14 ./1/0/cluster1.proc0.subproc0.swap
drwxr-xr-x 2 adesmet adesmet 4096 May 25 14:14 ./1/0/cluster1.proc0.subproc0.tmp

2012-May-25 14:34:36 by adesmet:
Analysis:

The directory tree $(SPOOL)/1/0/cluster1.proc0.subproc0.swap was created. The ownership is:

  • condor. $(SPOOL)/
  • condor. $(SPOOL)/1/
  • condor. $(SPOOL)/1/0/
  • adesmet $(SPOOL)/1/0/cluster1.proc0.subproc0.swap

When Condor tries to rmdir $(SPOOL)/1/0/cluster1.proc0.subproc0.swap, it does so as adesmet. adesmet doesn't have write access to $(SPOOL)/1/0/, so the attempt fails. I believe everything else that goes wrong chains from that failure.

Possible fixes:

  • Delete the directory as condor.
  • Have $(SPOOL)/1/0/ owned by adesmet

The "1/0" directories are relatively new; it used to be that you'd end up with $(SPOOL)/cluster1.proc0.subproc0.swap. I believe the addition of the 1/0 directories are the immediate cause. That doesn't necessarily explain why the code (presumably) worked in earlier releases.

2012-May-30 15:28:12 by adesmet:
Present at least as far back as 7.6.3

2012-May-30 15:34:57 by adesmet:
It's not feasible to have the intermediary directories (0/1) to be owned by adesmet; the directories are actually bucket, with clusters sorted into groups of 10000. Multiple people's jobs could be in those directories. We'll just need to clean up the topmost directory as condor.

2012-Jun-04 14:08:46 by adesmet:
Or, not. That just ends up leaking different directories. Could detect at run-time who the current owner is, but that seem fraught with non-portable (especially on Windows) code. Could try deleting both ways, but that raises questions like, "if both attempts fail, which errno is meaningful." I think the correct solution is to ensure directory ownership by condor in all cases.

2012-Jun-21 13:22:50 by adesmet:
Re: Code review: This code went in and out and back in because of problems. The "real" commit is bdb1033b [32261] .
